_**Legion**_ is an American [cable television](/wiki/Cable_television "Cable
television") series created for [FX](/wiki/FX_\(TV_channel\) "FX \(TV
channel\)") by [Noah Hawley](/wiki/Noah_Hawley "Noah Hawley"), based on the
[Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics") character [David Haller /
Legion](/wiki/Legion_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Legion \(Marvel Comics\)"). It is
connected to the [_X-Men_ film series](/wiki/X-Men_\(film_series\) "X-Men
\(film series\)"), the first television series to be so, and is produced by
[FX Productions](/wiki/Fox_Entertainment_Group "Fox Entertainment Group") in
association with [Marvel Television](/wiki/Marvel_Television "Marvel
Television"). Hawley serves as [showrunner](/wiki/Showrunner "Showrunner") on
the series.

[Dan Stevens](/wiki/Dan_Stevens "Dan Stevens") stars as Haller, a
[mutant](/wiki/Mutant_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Mutant \(Marvel Comics\)") diagnosed
with [schizophrenia](/wiki/Schizophrenia "Schizophrenia") at a young age.
[Rachel Keller](/wiki/Rachel_Keller_\(actress\) "Rachel Keller \(actress\)"),
[Aubrey Plaza](/wiki/Aubrey_Plaza "Aubrey Plaza"), [Bill
Irwin](/wiki/Bill_Irwin "Bill Irwin"), Jeremie Harris, [Amber
Midthunder](/wiki/Amber_Midthunder "Amber Midthunder"), [Katie
Aselton](/wiki/Katie_Aselton "Katie Aselton"), and [Jean
Smart](/wiki/Jean_Smart "Jean Smart") also star. FX and Marvel Television
announced a new collaboration to create a television series based on the
[X-Men](/wiki/X-Men "X-Men") character Legion in October 2015, with Hawley
signed on to write, and direct the pilot. Casting began by January 2016, and
filming took place in [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"). Hawley wanted
to show Haller as an "[unreliable narrator](/wiki/Unreliable_narrator
"Unreliable narrator")", including mixing 1960s design with modern-day
elements, and filming the series through the title character's distorted view
of reality.

The eight-episode [first season](/wiki/Legion_\(season_1\) "Legion \(season
1\)") of _Legion_ premiered at the [Pacific Design
Center](/wiki/Pacific_Design_Center "Pacific Design Center") on January 26,
2017, ahead of its FX debut on February 8. The series received critical
acclaim, particularly for its visuals and departure from superhero genre
standards. A ten-episode second season was ordered in March 2017 and is
planned for a February 2018 release.

##
Premise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Premise")]

David Haller was diagnosed with schizophrenia at a young age and has been a
patient in various psychiatric hospitals since. After Haller has an encounter
with a fellow psychiatric patient, he is confronted with the possibility that
there may be more to him than mental illness.[4]

## Cast and
characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast and characters")]

Main article: [List of Legion characters](/wiki/List_of_Legion_characters
"List of Legion characters")

  * [Dan Stevens](/wiki/Dan_Stevens "Dan Stevens") as [David Haller](/wiki/Legion_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Legion \(Marvel Comics\)"): 

The [mutant](/wiki/Mutant_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Mutant \(Marvel Comics\)") son of
[Charles Xavier](/wiki/Professor_X "Professor X"), Haller was diagnosed with
schizophrenia at a young age and meets the "girl of his dreams" in a
psychiatric hospital.[5][6] The character possesses various
[psychic](/wiki/Psychic "Psychic") abilities, including
[telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") and [telekinesis](/wiki/Telekinesis
"Telekinesis").[7] Stevens joined the series because of showrunner [Noah
Hawley](/wiki/Noah_Hawley "Noah Hawley")'s involvement,[6] and did extensive
research on mental health to prepare for the role, talking to both mentally
ill persons and doctors.[8] Hawley and the cast kept secrets from Stevens
about the character and plot so that he could identify with Haller's confusion
about himself and reality.[9]

  * [Rachel Keller](/wiki/Rachel_Keller_\(actress\) "Rachel Keller \(actress\)") as Sydney "Syd" Barrett: 

A young woman who becomes Haller's girlfriend.[5][6] Syd's mind trades places
with that of anyone she touches, with hers entering their body, and vice
versa.[7] Because of her abilities, the character is portrayed as "withdrawn",
the opposite of Keller's breakout performance in the [second
season](/wiki/Fargo_\(season_2\) "Fargo \(season 2\)") of Hawley's
_[Fargo](/wiki/Fargo_\(TV_series\) "Fargo \(TV series\)")_.[10] She is named
after [Roger "Syd" Barrett](/wiki/Syd_Barrett "Syd Barrett") of the rock band
[Pink Floyd](/wiki/Pink_Floyd "Pink Floyd"), whose music was an important
influence on the series for Hawley.[11]

  * [Aubrey Plaza](/wiki/Aubrey_Plaza "Aubrey Plaza") as Lenny Busker: 

Haller's friend, an "impossible optimist" despite a history of drug and
alcohol abuse.[5][6] The character dies in the first episode, but returns as
one form of the powerful mutant [Amahl Farouk / Shadow King](/wiki/Shadow_King
"Shadow King"), who appears in Haller's mind using several forms in addition
to Busker.[12] Busker was originally written for a middle aged man, until
Hawley met Plaza and rethought the character. However, Plaza insisted that the
character's dialogue not be changed for her, instead choosing to play the
character as both male and female. This led to Busker "making crass remarks
about women and muttering vintage phrases".[13]

  * [Bill Irwin](/wiki/Bill_Irwin "Bill Irwin") as Cary Loudermilk: 

A mutant scientist,[14][6][15] one of the founders of Summerland and one of
Bird's specialists.[16] The character is introduced in the second episode, but
Hawley sought to cast Irwin, for his "playful approach to characters", during
filming on the pilot, before the character's role had been written.[17][6]
Hawley "had to pitch him the weird, crazy character dynamic and that the show
is about memory and identity", and Irwin agreed to join the project.[18]

  * Jeremie Harris as Ptonomy Wallace: 

A former child prodigy,[19][6] one of Bird's specialists.[16] A "memory
artist", Ptonomy "remembers everything, and has the ability to take people
back into their own memories".[7]

  * [Amber Midthunder](/wiki/Amber_Midthunder "Amber Midthunder") as Kerry Loudermilk: 

A [savant](/wiki/Savant_syndrome "Savant syndrome") who lives inside Cary's
body; their mutant power allows them to coexist in one body or to become
separate physical persons.[20][6] Kerry only ages when she is outside Cary,
leaving her physically much younger than he is.

  * [Katie Aselton](/wiki/Katie_Aselton "Katie Aselton") as Amy Haller: 

David's older sister, who tries to remain positive despite his history of
mental illness.[21][6] Hawley said that she defined herself as normal "against
her brother. She finds herself being looked at as if she might be crazy, as
well."[15]

  * [Jean Smart](/wiki/Jean_Smart "Jean Smart") as Melanie Bird: 

A demanding psychiatric therapist.[5][16] Smart joined the series immediately
when asked by Hawley, despite knowing nothing about the show and its source
material, due to her previous [Emmy](/wiki/Emmy "Emmy")-nominated work with
him on the second season of _Fargo_.[22]

### Season
2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Season 2")]

FX renewed _Legion_ for a second season on March 15, 2017.[31] At the end of
that month, Hawley explained that he planned for the season to have ten
episodes, and to focus more on the series' other characters in addition to
David Haller.[32] Filming is set to begin in July 2017,[33] with the season
expected to begin airing in February 2018.[32]

See also: [Production of season 1](/wiki/Legion_\(season_1\)#Production

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Development")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Noah_Hawley_%2815042030244%29.jpg/170px-
Noah_Hawley_%2815042030244%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Noah_Hawley_\(15042030244\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Noah_Hawley_\(15042030244\).jpg "Enlarge")

Creator Noah Hawley set out to create a fresh take on the [superhero
genre](/wiki/Superhero_fiction "Superhero fiction").

After completing work on the [first season](/wiki/Fargo_\(season_1\) "Fargo
\(season 1\)") of _[Fargo](/wiki/Fargo_\(TV_series\) "Fargo \(TV series\)")_
at [FX](/wiki/FX_\(TV_channel\) "FX \(TV channel\)") in 2014, [Noah
Hawley](/wiki/Noah_Hawley "Noah Hawley") was presented with the opportunity to
develop the first live-action television series based on the
[X-Men](/wiki/X-Men "X-Men") comics, of which Hawley was a fan when growing
up.[34] Hawley was initially pitched two different ideas for the potential
series,[10] including an adaptation of the comics' [Hellfire
Club](/wiki/Hellfire_Club_\(comics\) "Hellfire Club \(comics\)"), but the
ideas did not interest Hawley. Instead, he worked with [_X-Men_ film
series](/wiki/X-Men_\(film_series\) "X-Men \(film series\)") writer and
producer [Simon Kinberg](/wiki/Simon_Kinberg "Simon Kinberg") to reverse-
engineer an idea for the series. After discussing an "interesting show in this
genre ... that isn't being done", the two settled on the character of [David
Haller / Legion](/wiki/Legion_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Legion \(Marvel Comics\)").
Hawley found the character interesting because of his mental illness, and for
the potential of the series to depict his unique mindset.[34] He pitched the
series as "a deconstruction of a villain ... and a love story".[10]

In October 2015, FX ordered a [pilot](/wiki/Television_pilot "Television
pilot") for _Legion_ , with [Marvel Television](/wiki/Marvel_Television
"Marvel Television") and [FX Productions](/wiki/Fox_Entertainment_Group "Fox
Entertainment Group") producing; FX Productions would handle the physical
production. Hawley was set to write the pilot, and executive produce the
series alongside _X-Men_ film producers [Lauren Shuler
Donner](/wiki/Lauren_Shuler_Donner "Lauren Shuler Donner"), [Bryan
Singer](/wiki/Bryan_Singer "Bryan Singer"), and Kinberg, Marvel Television
executives [Jeph Loeb](/wiki/Jeph_Loeb "Jeph Loeb") and Jim Chory, and
Hawley's _Fargo_ collaborator John Cameron.[4] Steve Blackman, [Alan
Fine](/wiki/Alan_Fine_\(executive\) "Alan Fine \(executive\)"), [Stan
Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee"), [Joe Quesada](/wiki/Joe_Quesada "Joe
Quesada"), and Karim Zreik also executive produce.[35] Hawley's initial script
for the series was described as "less fractured", "cohesive [and] much more
regular." However, he quickly reconceived the series "and decided more
_[Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless
Mind](/wiki/Eternal_Sunshine_of_the_Spotless_Mind "Eternal Sunshine of the
Spotless Mind")_ , [Terrence Malick](/wiki/Terrence_Malick "Terrence Malick"),
more whimsy, more impressionistic and went in that direction."[10] By January
2016, FX President [John Landgraf](/wiki/John_Landgraf "John Landgraf") was
confident that the series would be picked up by the network, saying that "the
vast majority of things that we pilot do go forward to series" and "the
scripts [for _Legion_] are extraordinary."[36] That May, FX ordered an eight-
episode first season of _Legion_.[14]

In June, Landgraf said that the series, if successful, could run for as many
seasons as Hawley feels it needs to tell the story.[37] Discussing future
seasons, Hawley said in January 2017 that he was open to continuing the story
past the first season, but didn't want the audience to get to the end of the
first run and have "no resolution of any kind at the end of it." Star [Dan
Stevens](/wiki/Dan_Stevens "Dan Stevens") said, "I know for a fact that there
are more issues that David has to deal with than the one that we really
address in the first season."[8] Also at that time, Singer explained the
executive producers' roles in the series, saying that he, Donner, and Kinberg
brought their experience from making the _X-Men_ films, but their involvement
generally consisted of giving small notes on scripts and early cuts of
episodes.[38] In March, FX ordered a second season of the series.[31] With the
end of the first season, Hawley said that the second season would consist of
ten episodes, and explained that he was unsure at that time how long he would
like the series to run: "I think there were things about the first season that
[I felt] would unfold faster than they did, and things that I thought would
take longer that I dealt with more quickly. I think by the end of the second
year I’ll have a better sense of how many more years there are to go".[32]

###
Writing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Writing")]

Kinberg teased in November 2015 that the series would tell "X-Men stories in a
slightly different way and even with a slightly different tone" from the
films, noting the differences in tone between the "operatic" _X-Men_ films and
the "irreverent and hysterical" _[Deadpool](/wiki/Deadpool_\(film\) "Deadpool
\(film\)")_ , and feeling that _Legion_ gives "us an opportunity to go even
further ... in some ways to sort of blow up the paradigm of comic book or
superhero stories and almost do our _[Breaking Bad](/wiki/Breaking_Bad
"Breaking Bad")_ of superhero stories."[39] Loeb noted that "the core" of all
_X-Men_ comic books has always been that "the X-Men were different ... We live
in a world right now where diversity and uniqueness and whether or not we fit
in is something that's on our minds twenty-four hours a day. The X-Men have
never been more relevant than they are right now." Hawley added, "The great
thing about exploring this character is before he has an opinion about anyone
else, he has to figure out his own shit. That's what we all have to do. This
journey isn't necessarily racing toward a battle with an entity, so much as
embracing the battle within."[6]

In May 2016, Hawley described his take on the series as being inspired by the
works of [David Lynch](/wiki/David_Lynch "David Lynch"), and said that "the
structure of a story should reflect the content of the story. If the story, as
in this case, is about a guy who is either schizophrenic or he has these
abilities, i.e., he doesn’t know what’s real and what’s not real, then the
audience should have the same experience ... my goal with this is to do
something whimsical and imaginative and unexpected. Not just because I want to
do something different, but because it feels like the right way to tell this
story."[40] Elaborating on structuring the series to reflect Haller's point of
view, Hawley said, "I love the idea that even when you're in it on the
journey, there is this _[Alice in Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland "Alice
in Wonderland")_ quality to it, of a story within a story."[34] Discussing the
increasing popularity of [unreliable narrators](/wiki/Unreliable_narrators
"Unreliable narrators") in television, Hawley said that he wanted to avoid
making the audience think that the series is a puzzle that needs to be solved
by solving the mysteries for them upfront—"We’re going to take a character out
of confusion into clarity and an audience out of mystery into clarity."[17]
Hawley deliberately chose not to directly adapt any storylines from the
comics, feeling that "you're bound to offend somebody, no matter what you do"
in that situation. Instead, he wanted to take the character of Legion and
basic set-up around him, and "play" with that,[34] which he described in
relation to _Fargo_ —"my job was not to remake [the
movie](/wiki/Fargo_\(film\) "Fargo \(film\)"), to sort of retell a story that
had already been told, but to try to tell a different story with the same
effect, the same impact."[41]

Concerning the mental illness aspects of the character, Hawley said, "It’s a
tragic condition that people have, and so I don’t want to use it for
entertainment purposes ... if we can ground that [aspect] for the audience,
then the idea that he’s fallen in love and that he’s not ill, there’s a hope
to that that the audience is gonna grab onto."[41] In January 2017, Hawley
explained that he was willing to use different tropes from the superhero genre
in the series, such as superhero costumes with capes, if necessary, but did
want to avoid "sending a message that all conflict can only be resolved
through battle. There is a sense in a lot of these stories that everything
always builds to a big fight ... I wanted to find a story that was just as
exciting and interesting but doesn’t send the message that in the end that
'might makes right'."[7] At the end of the first season, Hawley said, "I like
this idea of having to face our demons", with the first season seeing Haller
go through an internal struggle with the malevolent [Shadow
King](/wiki/Shadow_King "Shadow King") occupying his mind, and then the second
season seeing that character possess someone else "making it an exterior
agent. And there’s going to be something very complicated about going to war
with himself. It’s been with him since he was a baby, it’s like a [phantom
limb](/wiki/Phantom_limb "Phantom limb") now, it’s part of him." Hawley said
he preferred this idea of a villain "worthy of creating a whole story around",
rather than a villain-of-the year. He was unsure at the time how long that
storyline would continue throughout the show, but said "it’s a fascinating
setup to follow."[32]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Casting")]

In January 2016, [Rachel Keller](/wiki/Rachel_Keller_\(actress\) "Rachel
Keller \(actress\)") was cast as the female lead of the series, after her
breakout role in _Fargo_.[42] In early February, Stevens, [Aubrey
Plaza](/wiki/Aubrey_Plaza "Aubrey Plaza"), and [Jean Smart](/wiki/Jean_Smart
"Jean Smart") were cast as Haller, his friend Lenny Busker, and therapist
Melanie Bird, respectively. Keller's role was revealed to be Syd
Barrett.[5][6][16] Later that month, Jeremie Harris was cast in the regular
role of Ptonomy Wallace,[19] and [Amber Midthunder](/wiki/Amber_Midthunder
"Amber Midthunder") was cast as the [savant](/wiki/Savant_syndrome "Savant
syndrome") Kerry Loudermilk.[20][6] In March, [Katie
Aselton](/wiki/Katie_Aselton "Katie Aselton") was cast as Haller's older
sister Amy.[21] With the full series order in May 2016, [Bill
Irwin](/wiki/Bill_Irwin "Bill Irwin") was added to the cast,[14] in the role
of Cary Loudermilk.[6]

###
Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Design")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Thursday_Comic-
Con_2017_%2835259629313%29.jpg/220px-Thursday_Comic-
Con_2017_%2835259629313%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thursday_Comic-
Con_2017_\(35259629313\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Thursday_Comic-Con_2017_\(35259629313\).jpg "Enlarge")

An advertisement for the series at [San Diego Comic-
Con](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con "San Diego Comic-Con") 2017

Though he put little thought into the aesthetics of the series when writing
the pilot,[43] as a director Hawley wanted the series to be highly stylized,
describing his vision for it as "a 1964 [Terence Stamp](/wiki/Terence_Stamp
"Terence Stamp") movie".[44] It was not feasible to literally translate [Bill
Sienkiewicz](/wiki/Bill_Sienkiewicz "Bill Sienkiewicz")'s iconic artwork of
the character to the screen, and Hawley wanted the series to have "its own
visual aesthetic to it, and part of that is being a story kind of out of time
and out of place". He stated that "the design of a show has to have its own
internal logic", and compared this sensibility to the series
_[Hannibal](/wiki/Hannibal_\(TV_series\) "Hannibal \(TV series\)")_ , which he
said was "a great example of something that had this almost fetishistic beauty
to everything that you saw, whether it was food or violence."[41] Hawley
elaborated that the design choice of 60s British films came about because
"this whole show is not the world, it’s David’s _experience_ of the world.
He’s piecing his world together from nostalgia and memory and the world
becomes that."[7]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Filming")]

Filming for the pilot took place in [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver
"Vancouver"),[45] with Hawley directing and [Dana
Gonzales](/wiki/Dana_Gonzales "Dana Gonzales") serving as
cinematographer.[40][46] With the series order, the rest of the first season
were set to also film in Vancouver,[14][47] with Craig Wrobleski also working
as a cinematographer. Both Ganzales and Wrobleski previously worked with
Hawley on _Fargo_.[48] The pilot featured a large amount of in-camera effects,
which Hawley admitted would be a challenge for the series' directors to
maintain,[18] given he had 21 days to film the pilot, but the subsequent
episodes were only scheduled 8 days of filming each. Some of these shoots
ultimately had to be extended to 10 or 11 days filming to meet Hawley's
vision.[17] For the second season, the series relocated its production to
[California](/wiki/California "California") to take advantage of tax
incentives provided by the [California Film
Commission](/wiki/California_Film_Commission "California Film Commission")
under its "Program 2.0" initiative.[49]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Music")]

[Jeff Russo](/wiki/Jeff_Russo "Jeff Russo") was revealed to be composing the
series' score in October 2016.[11] Hawley stated that when first meeting with
Russo about the series, he told the latter that he wanted the series to sound
like [Pink Floyd](/wiki/Pink_Floyd "Pink Floyd")'s _[The Dark Side of the
Moon](/wiki/The_Dark_Side_of_the_Moon "The Dark Side of the Moon")_ ,
explaining "that album more than anything is really the soundscape of mental
illness to some degree".[44][11] Russo felt that "the important part is
allowing the humanity of these characters to really shine through", and in
addition to an orchestra he used "a bunch of old synthesizers" and "a lot of
interesting sound design" to represent the "otherworldly" elements of the
series.[50] With the series' premiere, Russo reiterated that the "through-
line" of the series is the relationship between Haller and Barrett, and said
that a love story "lends itself to musical moments. It allows it to underscore
the character." After his early meetings with Hawley, Russo developed some
initial ideas for the score, and created three different themes to represent
Haller. He adapted these ideas to fit the episodes once they had been
edited.[51] A soundtrack album for the [first
season](/wiki/Legion_\(season_1\) "Legion \(season 1\)") was released
digitally on February 24, 2017, on [Amazon.com](/wiki/Amazon.com
"Amazon.com").[52]

### Shared universe
connections[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Shared universe connections")]

Landgraf stated, in January 2016, that the series would be set in a [universe
parallel](/wiki/Parallel_universe_\(fiction\) "Parallel universe \(fiction\)")
to the _X-Men_ films where "the US government is in the early days of being
aware that something called mutants exist but the public is not". He felt it
was unlikely that characters would cross over between the show and films, but
noted that this could change between then and the premiere of the series.[36]
That July, an article on [Marvel.com](/wiki/Marvel_Entertainment "Marvel
Entertainment") referred to Legion as one of several characters joining the
[Marvel Cinematic Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic
Universe") (MCU), suggesting that _Legion_ would be set in that [shared
universe](/wiki/Shared_universe "Shared universe") like Marvel Television's
other series.[53] The next month, Singer said that _Legion_ had actually been
designed to fit into the _X-Men_ universe, but also to stand alone, so "you
wouldn't have to label" the relationship between the series and the films. He
teased plans to have the series "relate to future _X-Men_ movies".[54]

At [New York Comic-Con](/wiki/New_York_Comic-Con "New York Comic-Con") 2016,
Donner said that the series is "far from the _X-Men_ movies, but still lives
in that universe. The only way for _X-Men_ to keep moving forward is to be
original and to surprise. And this is a surprise. It is very, very different."
Hawley explained that because the series is depicting the title character's
"subjective reality", it would not have to address any connections to the
films straight away, noting that _Fargo_ , which is connected to the 1996 film
of the same name, at first "had to stand on its own feet" before exploring
those connections more; "We have to earn the right to be part of this
universe. My hope is we create something so strong that the people in the
movie studio call and say they would be foolish enough not to connect these
things." He did state that "you can't tell this story without" acknowledging
that Legion is the son of [Charles Xavier](/wiki/Professor_X "Professor X"),
who appears in the films. In regards to the MCU, Loeb stated that his
involvement in the series was a sign that "bridges are being made" between
Marvel and Fox, "but I don't want to make any promises ... Marvel heroes at
their core are people who are damaged and are trying to figure out who they
are in life. It doesn't matter whether or not they're X-Men, [Tony
Stark](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man"), [Matt
Murdock](/wiki/Daredevil_\(Marvel_Comics_character\) "Daredevil \(Marvel
Comics character\)") or [Peter Parker](/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-Man") ... If
you start at a place as strong as David's character is and you have a
storyteller like Noah, then it's Marvel. In that way, it _is_ all
connected."[6]

Loeb and Donner stated in January 2017 that there were no plans to have
_Legion_ be the first in a series of connected shows on FX, like Marvel
Television's group of interconnected
_[Defenders](/wiki/The_Defenders_\(miniseries\) "The Defenders
\(miniseries\)")_ series on [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix"),[55] and that
_Legion_ and the _X-Men_ series being developed for
[Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") are "not
going to get in each other's way."[10] Donner stated that the series was just
a chance to bring an X-Men character to the screen who was not going to be
used by the films. The producers hoped that audiences would watch the show
because of its character-focus and the talents of Hawley and the cast, rather
than to "see a Marvel franchise show."[55] Donner also noted that having
Hawley focus on Haller's perspective of reality rather than connections to the
_X-Men_ films allowed the series to avoid the convoluted continuity of the
films, "because we play with so many different timelines, and we rebooted and
not really rebooted and all that" throughout the films. Therefore, "the
cinematic universe will not worry about _Legion_. They will not worry about
these TV worlds at all. They will just continue in the way that they have been
continuing."[10] For the onscreen confirmation that Xavier is Haller's father
in "[Chapter 7](/wiki/Chapter_7_\(Legion\) "Chapter 7 \(Legion\)")", with
Xavier's signature wheelchair shown in a brief flashback, the series'
production was able to choose from any of the variant wheelchairs used
throughout the film series. They settled on the version from _[X-Men:
Apocalypse](/wiki/X-Men:_Apocalypse "X-Men: Apocalypse")_ , with the prop used
in that film being brought out of storage for the show.[12][22]

###
Broadcast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Broadcast")]

_Legion_ airs on FX in the United States,[16] while Fox channels in over 125
countries have picked up their respective airing rights for the series,
releasing the show using a "day-and-date" delivery system so that viewers
around the world get the series on the same day as the U.S. Fox Networks
Group's sales division handle distribution of the series to third parties.[57]

###
Ratings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Ratings")]

Writing for Screen Rant, J.M. Brandt noted that FX extensively advertised the
series, but was debuting the 90 minute (with commercials) premiere at 10:00 pm
on a Wednesday night, later than other genre "monster hits" like _[Game of
Thrones](/wiki/Game_of_Thrones "Game of Thrones")_ and _[The Walking
Dead](/wiki/The_Walking_Dead_\(TV_series\) "The Walking Dead \(TV series\)")_.
Brandt felt that the series' success would heavily depend on DVR viewing "to
bolster what might be a likely smallish live audience".[60] Following the
series premiere, _Legion_ 's debut ratings were described as "OK, not great",
in line with other cable series debuts, but lower than other high-profile FX
debuts such as _[American Crime Story](/wiki/American_Crime_Story "American
Crime Story")_ and Hawley's own _Fargo_.[61]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Legion_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") website
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reported a 90%
approval rating with an average rating of 8.37/10 based on 61 reviews. The
website's critical consensus reads, "Bold, intelligent, and visually
arresting, _Legion_ is a masterfully surreal and brilliantly daring departure
from traditional superhero conceits."[58] [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic
"Metacritic"), which uses a weighted average, assigned a score of 82 out of
100 based on 40 critics, indicating what the website considers to be
"universal acclaim".[59]
